question: Question_B_04_(a)
statement:
Let a={[}1,2,-1{]}. Consider the transformation
$T:\mathbb{R}^3\to\mathbb{R}^3$ defined by
$T(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a}$ for all \textbf{x} in
$\mathbb{R}^3$, where $\times$ is the cross-product in $\mathbb{R}^3$.

Show that T is a linear transformation.
sols:
Following the hint, we seek to show the properties of a linear
transformation,

\begin{align*}
T(\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{y})&=T(\mathbf{x})+T(\mathbf{y}),\\
T(c\mathbf{x})&=cT(\mathbf{x}).
\end{align*}

For the first property,

\begin{align*}
&T(\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{y})\\
&=(\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{y})\times\mathbf{a}\\
&=(\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a})+(\mathbf{y}\times\mathbf{a})\\
&=T(\mathbf{x})+T(\mathbf{y}),
\end{align*}

where we have used that the cross product is
\href{Wikipedia:Distributive}{distributive} over addition. The second
property holds by the compatibility of scalar multiplication with the
cross product,

\begin{align*}
&T(c\mathbf{x})\\
&=(c\mathbf{x})\times\mathbf{a}\\
&=c(\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a})\\
&=cT(\mathbf{x}).
\end{align*}

Therefore we have concluded that \emph{T} is a linear transformation.
